data.title: Penny Mordaunt could take over as PM - everything you need to know about Brexiteer
data.meta_description: PENNY MORDAUNT is one of the favourites to become the next prime minister and replace Boris Johnson. The Prime Minister announced his resignation on July 7, and Tory members are looking for who will take charge next. But who is Ms Mordaunt and why is she among the favourites?
data.text:
Boris Johnson: Lord Heseltine discusses future of Brexit

Penny Mordaunt is widely respected among Conservative Party members, who rank her as one of the favourites to take the reigns from Boris Johnson, according to a survey on July 12 by Conservative Home. Ms Mordaunt and former chancellor Rishi Sunak are among the favourites right now and are expected to put in a strong showing in the Tory leadership contest.

Who is Penny Mordaunt?

Ms Mordaunt is MP for Portsmouth North, a post she has held since 2010 and has a majority of 15,000 votes.

She won the seat from Labour in the 2010 general election, proving her ability to turn key swing states blue.

In September last year, she was appointed Minister of State at the Department for International Trade, and has served in successive Conservative governments.

Under David Cameron, Ms Mordaunt served as minister for local government, as well as becoming the first woman to be appointed armed forces minister.

According to her website, she was the first person in her family to go to university, and before politics she worked part-time alongside her Philosophy course at Reading.

She also had roles in communications and local government, and set up her own business before becoming director at Diabetes UK.

READ MORE: 'If Boris goes, Brexit goes' Lord predicts as issue now 'up for grabs'

She is a Brexiteer and backed the Vote Leave campaign in 2016 when the EU referendum was held.

Ms Mordaunt has accused the EU of “pushing its regulatory system on the rest of the world”, and described leaving the bloc as a “massive opportunity”.

She said in a speech last December: “Brexit is not an event to be mourned by the international community. Or an act of self-harm or one that requires us to be punished.

“It is a massive opportunity to anyone who believes in democracy and the power of trade as a force for good in the world.”

Invalid email

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

Why is she one of the favourites?

In the 2019 Tory leadership race, Ms Mordaunt did not stand, but instead endorsed Jeremy Hunt.

She has called for tax cuts as a way to boost the economy, going against Rishi Sunak’s approach which has seen National Insurance and corporation tax go up.

When she launched her Tory leadership campaign, she described herself as the candidate "Labour fears the most", and said the Conservative Party had "lost its sense of self" in recent times.

Her promises included low taxes, a small state, and an emphesis on personal respinsibiity.

DON'T MISS:

Michael Gove SACKED: Boris wields axe after ex-ally demanded PM resign [ANALYSIS]‘You’ve never run a Governent department!’ Nick Robinson erupts at min [REACTION]Why Queen will now play crucial role in end of Boris Johnson as PM[INSIGHT]

Other favourites in the race include former chancellor Rishi Suank, and Liz Truss, the foreign secretary.

Mr Sunak was an ally of Mr Johnson, but it was his resignation in the days before the Prime Minister announced he was stepping down, that led to a mass walk out in the Government.

Ms Truss has served key roles in British politics, and previously worked as a trade minister, helping to secure post-Brexit trade arangements with some of the world's biggest economies.

Tory MPs will vote on who they want to become the next prime minister, before the wider Tory membership has the final say, and Britain's next prime minister is announced on September 5.

But not all Tories are behind Ms Mordaunt, and some question whether she is the right person to take over the top job.

Stephen Carlton-Woods, 57, is a conservative political commentator who explained that he believes there are more suitable candidates.

He told Express.co.uk: “Penny is a lovely lady, but I don’t think she is a traditional Conservative, and I think whoever leads the party has to be a traditional Tory.”

Loyalties within the party are divided, and these will be played out publicly when the Conservative leadership election rolls around.

The new prime minister will take charge from September, and lead the Tory party into its conference in October, setting out the proprities of the new government.

The party wanted to have a new leader in place as it begins its campaign for the general election in 2024.

In the polls, the Labour Party and Sir Keir Starmer are comfortably ahead right now, and look likely to hold onto that after this week’s events.

But a new Tory leader could change the situation over the next 12 months if the party is able to find a leader who can bring its election chances back to life.
